page.title: 01Gotherington and Area
page.content: The area is largely rural with a mixture of sheep,dairy and arable farming. It is on the western edge of the Cotswold escarpment and possesses some fine rolling limestone hills the most notable being Dixton, Crane and Nottingham which form a semi-circle to the north and east around the village of Gotherington which, like Woolstone 1.5mls to the north and Stanley Pontlarge 3mls to the east, dates back to the first Domesday Survey.In Woolstone the church of St.Martin de Tours,which has Saxon origins, dominates the village whilst Stanley Pontlarge boasts a church with a fine Norman arch.Prescott Speed Hill Climb attracts visitors from a wide area. Cheltenham lies 5mls to the south, Tewkesbury 6mls to the north west and Winchcombe 5mls to the east of Gotherington.
